channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Municipal Debt Boom Is Driving Public Projects and Tax Breaks for Investors
item.description: Municipal debt issuance surpassed $500 billion last year, a record that’s found a deep pool of buyers.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith

item.title: What Americans Really Mean by ‘Affordability’
item.description: A few key necessities are driving dissatisfaction, particularly among the young, our poll finds.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn

item.title: Fed Meeting Comes at Pivotal Moment for Central Bank’s Independence
item.description: The Trump administration has unleashed a barrage of attacks on the Federal Reserve, including a criminal investigation into its chair, Jerome H. Powell.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: What to Watch as the Federal Reserve Meets
item.description: The central bank is expected to hold interest rates steady on Wednesday after a series of reductions in the latter half of 2025. The big question is how long the pause will last.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: As Trump Promotes Economy in Iowa, Many Residents Feel Pain
item.description: Farmers are critical to Iowa’s economy. They have been battered by President Trump’s tariffs and are not experiencing the “golden age” that the president promised.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Meta Campaigns to Change Opinions on Data Centers
item.description: The tech giant has spent more than $6 million on TV ads in state capitals and Washington, with the message that data centers create jobs.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan

item.title: Fed, Signaling Little Urgency, Prepares to Pause on Rate Cuts
item.description: The Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady on Wednesday, despite relentless attacks from President Trump over borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Record Debt in the World’s Richest Nations Threatens Global Growth
item.description: The cost of borrowing is already choking crucial public spending in many developing economies. Now it’s raising broader alarms.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Trump Administration Takes Another Stake in Rare Earth Sector
item.description: The administration announced a $1.6 billion deal with USA Rare Earth. The firm also does business with Cantor Fitzgerald, which is run by the sons of President Trump’s commerce secretary.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Says He Will Raise Tariffs on South Korea to 25%
item.description: President Trump threatened to increase tariffs on South Korean exports, including cars, citing the country’s slow ratification of a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Why Trump’s Reversal on Greenland Still Leaves Europe on Edge
item.description: Andrew Ross Sorkin, editor at large of DealBook, describes how leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos remain on edge after President Trump, for now, backed down from threats of using tariffs or military force to gain Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Rebecca Suner, Coleman Lowndes, Laura Salaberry and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: Trump Returns to a Familiar Role: Sowing Trade Chaos
item.description: The president’s quick reversal on tariffs over Greenland was another sign of his willingness to rip up the international order — even parts of it that he himself has made.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Threatens New Trade War as Court Weighs Whether to Check Him
item.description: President Trump may be on the verge of having his authority on imposing tariffs curtailed, but that hasn’t slowed down his threats.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tony Romm

item.title: Twin Falls, Idaho Has New Residents: 37 Afrikaners
item.description: Twin Falls needs immigrants, but the Trump administration has limited the refugee program to white South Africans.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan and Loren Elliott

item.title: At a Seattle Port Rocked by Tariffs, There Were 70 Jobs for 600 Workers
item.description: Dock workers are used to uncertainty, but nothing since the Great Recession of 2008 compares to what they have experienced this year.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin and Ruth Fremson

item.title: Trump’s Trade Negotiator Says Response to Court Loss Would Be Immediate
item.description: If the Supreme Court rules against its tariffs, the Trump administration would begin replacing them immediately, said Jamieson Greer, the United States Trade Representative.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: I.M.F. Raises Forecast for Global Growth as Tariff Drag Fades
item.description: The 3.3 percent rate for 2026 would match last year’s pace. Booming investment in artificial intelligence is buttressing global output.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Trump Imposes Limited Tariffs on Foreign Semiconductors
item.description: The tariffs will allow President Trump to take a cut of Nvidia’s chip sales to China while putting off a decision about imposing higher taxes on the chip industry.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tripp Mickle

item.title: Trump Credits ‘Mister Tariff’ for the Country’s Strength. Economists Beg to Differ.
item.description: Many indicators appear to suggest that the United States is growing despite tariffs, not because of them.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: 2026 May Be the Year of the Mega I.P.O.
item.description: If SpaceX, OpenAI and Anthropic go public, they will unleash gushers of cash for Silicon Valley and Wall Street.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith and Lauren Hirsch
